trial_identification.studytitle: Effects of azitromycin on Hospitalized Infants With Acute Bronchiolitis: A Randomized, prospective, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effects of azitromycin on length of hospital stay in Infants With Acute Bronchiolitis: A Randomized, prospective, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.

interventions.interventions: Azitromycin - oral syrup Dose 10mg/kg/day - oral 7 days
interventions.comparator: Placebo, micro cellulose syrup, in the same amount that azitromycin (10mg/kg/day) - oral - 7 day

primaryOutcome.outcome: Reduction in the length of hospital stay (length of the hospital stay or the time until the infant was ready for discharge according medical records).

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Duration of need for supplemental oxygen, assessed by medical and nursing records.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Infants less than 7 months of age who were admitted to Hospital de Clínicas de Porto Alegre between March 2009 and July 2010 with a first episode of wheezing requiring hospitalization and supplemental oxygen, with a clinical diagnosis of bronchiolitis
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Infants with cardiac, metabolic disease or clinically significant respiratory disease, such as cystic fibrosis, were not eligible, although infants with chronic neonatal lung disease associated with prematurity were included. Infants were excluded if they had received corticosteroids in any form within 7days before presentation or had received macrolides before presentation.

trial_design.concealment: After written informed parental consent had been obtained, the infants were randomly assigned to receive seven doses of azitromicin or placebo, after 12 hours after their admission to the hospital. Allocaction was concealed contacting the holder of the allocation schedule who was “off-site”
